it is an Easter play that dramatizes the meeting of the Risen Christ and his Mother.
A short musical role comedy popular during the 18<sup>th</sup> century. They were exaggerated comedies shown between acts of long plays and were mostly performed by characters from lower classes.
It's about a Christian princess who is captured by the Mohameddans. The father organizes a rescue party where fighting between the Moros and the Christians ensue.
It is a musical comedy or melodrama in three acts which dealt with a man's passions and emotions like love, hate, revenge, cruelty, avarice, or some social or political problem.
A ritual is performed based on a legend about a princess who dropped her ring into the middle of the sea and who offered her hand in marriage to anyone who can retrieve it.

Is a poetic joust or a contest of skills in debate on a particular topic or issue.

It is the art of written work and can, in some circumstances, refer exclusively to published sources.
This includes biographies, history, essays, speech, and narrative non-fiction
Is a short literary composition that reflects the author's outlook or point.
This is a report of everyday events in society, government, science and industry, and accidents, happening nationally, locally, or internationally.
It gives the history of a person's life, written or told by that person
It is the ability to express one's thoughts and emotions by speech, sounds, and gesture.
This is a formal treatment of a subject and is intended to be spoken in public.
Without Seeing the Dawn by Stevan Javellan is a
This genre is stories composed in verse or prose, usually for theatrical performance, where conflicts and emotion are expressed though dialogue and action
It is a story about supernatural or extraordinary people usually in the form of narration that demonstrates a useful truth.
It is the faculty of perceiving what is amusing or comical. Fiction full of fun, fancy, and excitement which meant to entertain.
The stories are about fairies or other magical creatures, usually for children.
It is a story based on impact of potential science, either actual or imagined.
These are songs, stories, myths, and proverbs, of a person of "folk" that was handed down by word of mouth.
The Bicol Legend is written by

It is a type of legend or traditional narrative. This is often based in part on historical events, that reveals human behavior and natural phenomena by its symbolism; often pertaining to the actions of the Gods.
This is presented on a stage, is divided into acts and each act has many scenes.
Thirteen Plays is written by
It is an overwhelming and painful feeling caused by literature that is frightfully shocking, terrifying, or revolting.
These are merely products of the writer's imagination and the main aim is to bring out lessons to the reader.
This is a narrative involving one or more characters, one plot, one single impression.
It is a series of events or episodes that make up the action. It is the skeletal structure of the story.
The clash between conflicting forces within the heart or mind of the protagonist.
It is the cause or reason that compels a character to act as he does.
It is a struggle between conflicting forces  within the heart or mind of the protragonist.
The point of high interest or dramatic intensity. Usually it marks the turning point in the action,  since the reader is no longer in doubt about the outcome.
The part when the characters get what he wants and the result is satisfactory or his wishes go unsatisfied and the ending is either happy or sad.
It is the final action. It is the unveiling of the plot, following the climax in which the writer explains how and why everything turned out as it did.
The person in a play or story; sometimes an animal or object.
A character who changes or develops during the course of the story.
A character whose actions, decisions, attitudes, feelings are kept in keeping with that the authot has led the reader to expect.
A general over-all feeling of a story conveyed in large part by the setting and the mood. This includes setting, the time, the place, the occupation and the conditions.
The idea, general truth or commentary on the life of people brought out in the story.
The method used by the author to tell his story; the position, psychological as well as physical, from which he presents what happens and the characters involved in it.
An object that stands for or represents an idea, belief, superstition, social or political in institution.
Is verse and rhythmic writing with imagery that evokes an emotional response from the reader.
It creates suspense and encourages the reader to go on and find out more about the event that is being foreshadowed.
The method used by the author to tell his story; the position, psychological as well as physical, from which he presents what happens and the characters involved in it.
The male character who is usually the central or main character, also called a protagonist.
The force (usually a person) that appears to go against the main character.
An outcome of event that rewards the virtues and punishes the vicious and ending in which each character gets exactly what he deserves.
A manner of writing in which people and events are presented as they are in real life, without romantic or realistic coloring.
The lesson or teaching that is brought out through the action or is explicitly stated or implied by one of the characters.
Dramatic device by which the author interrupts the episode to present a situation or incident which occurred at an earlier time.
The events following the climax, sometimes called falling action.
